reviewText: I have a special place in my heart for ghost/exorcist films even though most of them fall short of being good. This certain movie has to be one of the biggest wastes of 65 min. Even at that short of a length the film was too long and too slow. Nothing exciting happened until the last 20 minutes and there was no way to salvage this film. If you've ever seen a movie about a haunting you know the story:  new big house; creepy legend surrounding the house; little girl with an imaginary friend; etc. It's not even the fun bad, just plain terrible. I would not wish this torture on my worst enemy (which there are many). Let this be a warning and do not make the same mistake I made by purchasing/renting this movie.

reviewText: Confession: I haven't actually watched this movie yet but I always try to watch the trailer online before renting or purchasing movies on Amazon. By the looks of the DVD cover this movie seems to be a really creepy, scary supernatural horror. However, the trailer reveals the same old tricks and effects that horror fans have seen a dozen times before... only on a much lower budget. Girl suspended in air, woman dragged offscreen by unseen force, etc. So happy I didn't jump the gun and rent without seeing the trailer first because it would have been a waste of money.You should also know that Im pretty easy to please in the scary movie department and will watch almost anything (except for the super cheesy, not-even-scary horror flicks) so for me to be writing this review has to be saying something. Low budget doesn't always equal bad movie (watch Absentia to see what I mean!)Proceed at your own risk. : )
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is your stock Blair Witch clone with a (very minor) twist: instead of embarking on a quest to investigate and expose the Big Bad, our intrepid film crew is going there to disprove and debunk it.  If you guessed that said Big Bad turns out to be only oh too real, you're not going to be terribly surprised or frightened by anything this film has to offer.The problem with this film is that it didn't quite know what it wanted to be.  While it's nigh impossible to be the next Blair Witch (the found tapes trope is getting awfully tired,) more competent writing could have put this film in the same realm as the Lost Tapes series that used to play on Animal Planet...  predictable but entertaining.  More ego, a higher budget, or a proper grasp of camp could have pushed it into the realm of Sharknado, Birdemic and The Room; films that are hilariously bad.Conviction is really where this film falls flat.  It's like each of the characters was assigned a trait/stereotype and told to run with it for the duration of the film without ever questioning why.  (Mild spoiler alert) MItch, the leader of our group, is a skeptic who (as stated above) sets out to debunk the Grey Man (a local spirit haunting a family.)  He clearly states that while he intends to use the standard ghost hunting tropes of psychics/ouija boards, spirit bells (are these a thing?) and EMF gauges, he is doing so to later debunk them to the family and the world, thus proving that "there's nothing to be afraid of."Once Mitch discovers irrefutable proof that there's some truth to the legend, you'd think his plans would change, and that as a skeptic and a film maker who would stand to make millions off proof of the paranormal, he would discard the charade and continue his investigation into the legend in earnest.  For some inexplicable reason, he doesn't do this, and decides (with, baffling enough, the bulk of his team's agreement) that in order to help this family they must use techniques they don't believe in to debunk a spirit they know exists.  Oh, and they must film AT ALL TIMES because, y'know, found footage.This lack of basic logic makes the film come across as some sort of rough draft; the kind of thing a film school freshman may come up with at 6 AM for a project that's due at 8.  While I don't intend to spoil anything, the basic concept is so shoddy that the last ten minutes are a train wreck.  It was like the cast and crew had run out of money and just decided to close the film out in the fastest way possible.Was this film worth watching?  It all depends on how much you're willing to spend to watch someone fail... not epically, bud badly enough to be memorable.
Title: N/A

reviewText: It was ok. I love found footage films. There are good ones and there are bad ones. This one was ok. The premise, without giving too much away, is that a group of "film makers" set out to take advantage of a family who seems to be affected by an old legend. They go as far as to use one of their members as a "psychic". Eventually, things begin to happen, but before they realize that hey, maybe this is real, they begin having "issues". By then...it's too late. Like all of these movies go into it with a clear mind and leave all of your precognitions behind and you just might enjoy it.

reviewText: I'm 53 minutes into this and I wish I could get a refund for the dollar I paid to rent it.  This is literally a bunch of friends have some video cameras and there is no script.  There are more awkward pauses, "um's" and insincere "acting" (I use that term loosely) than I've seen in videos I made with my friends in 7th grade.  They claim if you love those lame ghost shows on TV, you'll love this.  Uhh...no.  I'm serious when I say it's like your neighbors came over and said "hey, we've smoked a little homegrown, wanna make a ghosty movie?" and you reply "I have no acting experience" and they say "neither do we."  Okay, it just ended and we looked at each other with no words adequate to describe the pile of dung we just wasted our lives on.  Rent at your own risk because I'm pretty sure the only people who bought this are the relatives of the people in the movie.
summary: Can I give zero stars please?
Title: N/A

reviewText: I've made it a personal quest to see all "found film" horror movies ever made.  Ever sinceParanormal Activity, I've been fascinated with the idea of someone actually documenting the supernatural.  Or at least watching someone else try to do it.So, I was honor bound to watch "Documenting the Grey Man".  It's easy to see why you can buy it on Amazon Instant Video for $3.  And that's a shame, because the plot offered so much potential.The film is only one hour and four minutes long, including the credits.  It's your typical cops-go-to-haunted-house-to-find-missing-people-but-find-a-video-tape-instead horror movie.  But the entire first half, some 30+ minutes, is dedicated to "setting the scene": discussing why the fraudulent "ghost hunters" are making this movie; interviews with the supposed victims of the Grey Man; tours of the many rooms of the Sims Manor; long, cricket chirping views of the haunted house.  It would've been great as a setup if anything interesting happened in the final half of the movie.  Instead, while the cast is talking about wrapping up the interviews and getting to the real ghost hunting, there's a scream and a single shot (rather well done, I must admit) of the daughter levitating over her bed.  "Finally", you think, "something spooky is going to happen!"Except it doesn't.Instead you're quickly redirected to a jump shot of the lead actor babbling about how "crazy tonight has been", followed by about another 20 minutes or so of the cast discussing why the "investigation" must go on.  Apparently no one thought to actually view the video of the levitating child.Another ten minutes are filled up by a fake medium that encourages everyone to "concentrate" on the questions he's posing over an admittedly bizarre looking Ouija board.  Finally, there is four minutes of extremely amateurish injuries to the various cast members and a repeat of the opening credits that what was shown was verified by the authorities as "authentic".So why give it two stars?  Maybe it's the college professor in me.  The one who would've said: "Nice try.  Now go back and make something interesting."
summary: Looks like a film school graduation project.  One that got a "D"
Title: N/A
